The Foreign Secretary said that the Cabinet should be aware of the background to the criticism which was now being directed at the United Kingdom Government by certain political elements in France on the subject of Libya. Having failed themselves to persuade the Libyan Government to meet their requirements in theFezzan, the French Government had tried to induce us to use our influence with the Libyan Government to achieve their aims. Hehad not been willing to jeopardise on this account our close andcordial relations with the Libyan Government; but he had nowsucceeded in securing Libyan agreement to the holding of staff talks between ourselves and the French about the arrangements whichwould be brought into operation in the Fezzan in the event of war.Under the arrangements now contemplated the role of the french in Libya in war would be entirely subordinate to our own.The Cabinet-Took note with approval of the Foreign Secretary'sstatement.Atomic Energy.WeaponsProgramme.(previous reference:CC. The Prime Minister said that other Commonwealth PrimeMinisters had now been informed of the Government^ decision toproceed with the development and production of thermo-nuclear weapons. The Government would be embarrassed if there were any premature disclosure of this decision, and he had thought it right that the Cabinet should have an opportunity of considering whether an official announcement should be made in advance of the publica-tion of the Defence White Paper. He himself was satisfied that publicreception of this decision would be less favourable if it were announced in isolation; and he would much prefer that it shouldbe made public in the White Paper in the context of the Govern-menfs defence policy as a whole.The Cabinet were reminded that a White Paper was also to be presented on the civil uses of atomic energy. It had been assumedhitherto that this would be published a few days before the defence white Paper. There would be advantage in publishing the Govern-menfs programme for civil development of atomic energy beforeannouncing their decision to produce thermo-nuclear weapons. Thiswas an additional reason for announcing the latter decision in theDefence White Paper.The Cabinet Agreed that the Governments decision to proceed with thedevelopment and production of thermo-nuclear weaponsshould be announced in the Defence White Paper, whichwas due to be presented to Parliament on 17th FebOx u-cii y. Farm Price 5. The Cabinet were informed that the Economic policy review. Committee had considered the objectives which the agriculture ministers should have in mind in their forthcoming negotiations withthe farmers' representatives on prices for farm products in the coming year. They had agreed that the Agriculture Ministers should aim at reaching an agreed settlement with the farmers' representatives on prices which would have the effect of reducing the exchequer subsidy by something between 8 millions and 13 millions. Thisrelief should be secured mainly by reductions in the prices for pigs,eggs and wheat, offset by increases in the prices for beef and mutton.The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that in the report by theCommittee on Civil Expenditure, which the Cabinet had considered on 20th July, it had been assumed that this review of farm pricesmight result in a saving to the Exchequer of 30 millions. In view,however, of the bad summer and the upward trend in production costs, he was now satisfied that it would be unrealistic to expect the farmers to accept any greater reduction in the level of government subsidy than that envisaged by the Economic Policy Committee.The Cabinet-Took note of these statements.Cabinet Office, S.W.1,5th February, 1955.\
